properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Major winter storm Sunday into Monday. An intense low pressure system is expected to bring a significant mix of wintry precipitation to much of northern Ontario Sunday into Monday, including snow, ice pellets and freezing rain. Some areas may see rain as well. Significant ice accumulation may be possible and widespread power outages are expected where freezing rain is the primary form of precipitation. Additionally, strong easterly winds may accompany the precipitation, particularly on Monday. Travel is expected to rapidly deteriorate Sunday morning. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T03:04:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T11:05:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1613636049.2019
Area: Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park, Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Searchmont - Montreal River Harbour - Batchawana Bay, Manitoulin Island

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds tonight and Saturday. A sharp trough over the Pacific Ocean will approach Haida Gwaii tonight then reach the mainland coast early Saturday. Strong southeasterly winds will rise as the system approaches, reaching up to 90 km/h on Haida Gwaii and on exposed coastal sections of the North Coast mainland. Winds will peak tonight over Haida Gwaii and Saturday morning on the mainland. ### Damage to buildings, such as to roof shingles and windows, may occur. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-28T16:07:47-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T00:08:47-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3606606826.2019
Area: Haida Gwaii, North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Ice storm possible Sunday into Monday. Freezing rain mixed with ice pellets and snow at times are expected to develop Sunday morning or Sunday afternoon. The freezing rain or ice pellets may taper off briefly Sunday night but will redevelop early Monday and continue through the day. The freezing rain or ice pellets will finally transition to flurries Monday afternoon. Significant ice accumulation and widespread power outages are expected. Travel is expected to deteriorate Sunday morning. Travel conditions could be very poor on Monday. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T03:02:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T11:03:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3942558187.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall Sunday and Monday. An intense low pressure system is expected to bring heavy snow to a large portion of northwestern Ontario. There may also be drifting snow in some areas. Snow is expected to begin Sunday morning and quickly intensify Sunday afternoon. The snow should become light Sunday night however it is expected to reintensify again Monday morning. The snow may be mixed with ice pellets at times Monday afternoon. On Sunday 5 to 10 cm of snow is expected in some communities. Additional amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible on Monday. Travel is expected to rapidly deteriorate Sunday morning. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T03:25:35-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T11:26:35-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3228634438.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain possible Sunday afternoon into Monday afternoon. Periods of rain are expected to develop Sunday afternoon and continue into early Monday afternoon. Temperatures will be very close and even just below the freezing mark in some areas. As a result there will be the threat for areas of freezing rain. Locally icy roads and sidewalks are expected. In some areas, temperatures may be just cold enough to allow for ice to accumulate on trees and hydro lines. This could result in power outages. Travel is expected to be very poor Sunday afternoon through Monday afternoon. Freezing rain warnings may be issued as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T01:37:44-00:00

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant Snowfall Sunday and Monday. An intense low pressure system is expected to bring heavy snow to a large portion of northwestern Ontario. There may also be drifting snow in some areas. Snow is expected to begin overnight and quickly intensify Sunday morning. Snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by Sunday evening. Freezing drizzle may also be mixed with the snow at times Sunday afternoon. The snow should become light Sunday night, however, it is expected to reintensify again Monday morning, especially near Lake Superior. Additional amounts of 10 to 20 cm on Monday are possible for some communities. Travel is expected to rapidly deteriorate Sunday morning. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T03:24:03-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Freezing rain Sunday and Monday morning. Periods of rain are expected to develop near noon on Sunday and continue through Sunday night into Monday morning. However, temperatures are forecast to be very close to the freezing mark. As a result, freezing rain will be mixed with the rain. Travel is expected to be very poor Sunday. Locally icy roads and sidewalks are expected. If the precipitation falls mainly as freezing rain, power outages may occur. Freezing rain warnings may be issued as the event draws nearer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Early morning temperatures near minus 38 degrees are expected. Falling surface pressures over the southern Yukon will generate increasing northeasterly winds today. As a result wind chill values will range from minus 50 to 55 this morning. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T02:04:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T12:52:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4168778701.2019
Area: Old Crow
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chill conditions near -55 will continue today. Warmer temperatures are expected beginning overnight tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T01:23:36-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T11:30:36-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0284859192.2019
Area: Sachs Harbour
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. A low pressure centre moving across the northern Gulf of Alaska will result in falling pressure over the Yukon this morning. This will combine with higher pressure over the Northwest Territories to generate strong easterly winds today. The resulting blizzard conditions will affect almost the entire Dempster, including the Ogilvie Mountains. In addition, extreme wind chill values near minus 50 are expected. The blizzard conditions are expected to ease through this evening. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T04:53:17-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T12:54:17-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3581883899.2019
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm Monday. Occasional light snow or ice pellets are expected Sunday night. However, heavier precipitation is then forecast to arrive Monday morning, then continue into Monday evening before transitioning to snow Monday night. There is considerable uncertainty as to the type of the heavier precipitation Monday. At this time freezing rain seems more likely however there are some indications that ice pellets could be the primary type of precipitation. Travel is expected to be very poor Monday. If the precipitation falls mainly as freezing rain there is the potential for an ice storm resulting in significant ice accumulation and widespread power outages. Environment Canada will continue to closely monitor this developing situation. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T01:44:27-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T09:45:27-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2989614387.2019

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor weather expected Monday... An intense low pressure system will reach the Great Lakes Monday and bring a mixed bag of snow and ice pellets over Southwestern Quebec. Precipitation amounts of approximately 15 centimetres are expected. Moreover, strong easterly winds could produce blowing snow locally. Precipitation could also fall as freezing rain at times Monday, especially over areas near the border of Ontario. As the exact track of this low could change, the types and amounts of precipitation could be subject to change. With this poor weather, road conditions should deteriorate. Consider the possibility of leaving early or delaying non-essential travel. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-29T01:53:14-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-28T09:54:14-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3636271318.2019
